lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: You wake up in an alleyway. The concrete around you is broken, and you spot numerous black feathers fluttering to the ground. You feel like you just got backhanded *hard*.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
For a moment, you feel the urge to cast *Identify* on yourself. You worry about the eight hour casting time, and the material components, but sanity (limited as that might be) washes over you, as you remember your magic isn't *that* kind of magic.

Looking down, you see a blue coat, gray shirt, and dark gray pants, with black boots on your feet. A white rhombus sits on your coat, where it should be. You feel a bit odd, as though perhaps whatever knocked you here has possibly knocked something loose in your mind? Or maybe the world itself is just *weird*.

The feathers around you are very similar to a certain other feather you encountered before, though these seem to have been damaged, as though something smashed into the wings and knocked them loose.

You feel the urge to hug your girlfriend, but she's nowhere nearby. Terribly rude of reality to do that to you.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You catch one of the last feathers still in the air and swiftly give it a good lick. It tastes feathery and ticklish. You feel vaguely dirty having done that, though you're not entirely certain why you would feel that way. You're rather uncertain about quite a bit right now. But there are two things you're certain of, and one of them you can address right now.

"Coobie, I'm going need you to fuck off *right* now, okay? Just fuck right the hell off. All of the go fuck yourself. I am depleting the universe's reserve of fucks to make you off."

You're not entirely certain you made much sense there, but that's never stopped you before. But now, you have something far more important to do. You heave yourself upright and stumble toward the end of the alleyway.

*"Mmami?"* you call out telepathically, and possibly out loud.

Yeah, you need to find Mami. This alleyway is decidedly lacking in Mamis. An irretrievable shortcoming.

There's no answer over telepathy. Maybe you shouldn't have pre-emptively depleted the universe of fucks to tell the Incubator to fuck off? Naaah.

How to find Mami, though...

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
After a moment of mental fumbling, you realize the answer is obvious. You immediately leap up, intending to roofhop to some place tall. Unfortunately, you shoulder-plant into the wall of a nearby building on the way up. Fortunately, you  push off of the wall and continue upward, but at the cost of smacking into the other building on the opposite side of the alleyway.

Two more leaps and some amount of property damage later, you're on rooftop level. You spot a nearby high-rise and immediately start racing for it, bounding across the cityscape. Or on a few occasions through it, but in your defense, you hit a pigeon! It was very distracting! You're sure the poor office lady will be alright, none of the glass hit her or nearby her.

You make it up to the top of the high rise, glancing down for a moment, and feeling a strange sense of vertigo.

"Remember kids, drink your school, stay in sleep, don’t do milk, and get eight hours of drugs."

Now for the sign. A *big* sign. Something Mami would see and immediately realize it was for her. Can't be her name, because there's a bunch of Mamis. Only one *Mami*, of course, but names are so important that others have her name because they need to be important?

You shake out your head, dismissing the thought. You don't have any grief on you, but you have some in your soul gem. It doesn't take long to pull that out, clone it, and create a hundred-meter wide heart made out of golden neon gas, blinking as you carefully manipulate the electrical currents through it.

You're pretty sure you forgot something about how this is supposed to work, but it's made of neon and it's emitting light. Electrical arcs too, but that's just the broken eggs of your omelette with Mami.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
Wait a minute! In your haste to find your Mami, you've completely forgotten about Homura! Yes, your girlfriend is *very* important, but Homura can help you find her! And she needs headpats and hugs. She's just been through so much.

*"Hommurraaaah! I can't find Mami! Also, I need your help stealing Yuma's nose. It's far too cute. Too much squeeing is bad for you, even if Kyouko doesn't squee."*

While you're trying to get Homura's help, you check your head for bumps. You find one, but after a moment, you realize it's your nose.

"Okay, this isn't working!" you yell toward a helicopter that's hovering in the distance, "I'm gonna need a phone. Wait, no, a *mega*phone. That's a million times better, it's in the name!"

You're not sure how long it takes, but you have a megaphone in hand. You look around at the skyline, to aim it for home to get Mami's attention, but you can't seem to find the building.

That having failed, you type " M A M I ❤ " into the megaphone touchscreen, bring it up to your mouth, and yell into it.

"MAMI! I need a hug! Please?"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Huh. There's another helicopter hovering nearby. That's weird.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
Oh. Okay, maybe you miscalculated. Kyuubey isn't mindwiping the helicopters. Wait, if he's not mindwiping the helicopters, maybe they know where Mami is? You look around and spot the nearest helicopter, then type "H E L I C O P T E R" into your megaphone and point it toward the nice little helicopter.

"Excuse me, do you know where my girlfriend is? She's Mami, Mami Tomoe, the best magical girl in the whole wide world. If you help me find her, I can pay you in yakuza gold, or give you a hug. Everyone needs hugs at times, and I would *really* like it if I could get a hug from Mami, so if you would please stop flying away from me, that would be REALLY NICE!"

The little helicopter is flying even further away, getting smaller all the time. The wonders of technological advance, miniaturization happens so fast nowadays.

And still no response from anyone. This is *not* good. Mami or Homura should be coming after you, unless something has gone *really* wrong. You look around, trying to find where 'doka's homu is, but you get confused trying to figure out if that means Madoka lives in Homura, and what the implications would be for your family tree.

"Focus, me," you remind yourself, "I need to find where Mami is, and everyone else too."

Looking around, you try to figure out which Mitakihara you're in, because you think it gets fencier sometimes? Maybe in later loops? Either way, this is a very unfency city, so this must be an early timeline. So early that even the river isn't there! That's pretty early. Maybe you're in a negative loop? You cleanse your soul gem, just to be on the safe side.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
Right, none of that is working. You need to bring in *everyone*.

*"**EVERYONE!** I NEED TO FIND MAMI TOMOE! PLEASE, I'LL GIVE THINGS! I know people don't like to help if there's nothing in it for them, so I'll give you things, I just want to find Mami."*

You decide to go down the street and ask bystanders if they've seen your Mami. You dutifully reshape your grief megaphone into a gas-mask, and start walking down the street. Unfortunately, the street doesn't cooperate, and you promptly fall off the top of the building you were on. But you're able to pull your grief back to you and turn it into immense wings in a jiffy, easiest thing there is, easy as falling, easy as falling in love.

As you fly down, you see crowds of people scattering, and you're preeeetty sure they're screaming. Weird. By the time you land, no-one is there, which is *really* annoying. Oh, but there's a whole bunch of cars nearby! You head over to the nearest one, ignoring the crunching, crumbling sounds behind you, and tap on the window, leaning down to see them clearly.

"Have you seen my Mami?"

The man inside the car screams and flails at the door to his car, managing to open it, and then gets caught on his seatbelt for a moment, before fleeing. Huh. All the people in the traffic are running away. You've missed something. Actually, you're pretty sure you've missed a lot. And you're missing Mami a lot.

"Mami?!"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
Wait, hold the megaphone. Or gas mask. Whichever.

What if this isn't even Mitakihara?

You look around, craning your neck, though not tilting your head, because that's too weird.

Huh.

You're pretty sure most of the street signs in Mitakihara aren't in English. Sure, their middle schools are SUPER advanced, and everyone probably knows English better than England, but the signs were still in Japanese.

"Oh, *that's* why it's not fency enough!"

Okay, you're not in Mitakihara, so you should probably be on your best behaviour. You reflect on your hometown when you go abroad, after all! You turn to check what the crunching sounds behind you were, only for a horrible shrieking cacophony to erupt behind you.

"Whoops. Uh, right, wings. Um, sorry building! Sorry, cars! Hopefully this isn't like Cars and you're not alive!"

Maybe you should get rid of the wings. Yeah, that'd probably be for the best. You dismiss all of your griefy things, condensing it down to cloned marbles, neatly arranging them in complex patterns. You need to be nice and sweet, so you arrange the marbles in nuclear models of fructose molecules, that way everyone will know you're friendly.

Right, now you need to find someone less shouty. Oh, those are police officers, that's no good, cops are *very* shouty.

"Freeze!" "Hands in the air!"

Yep, *very* shouty.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"I'm sorry, officer, I don't have freezing powers," you explain, "I mean, I think it would be kinda obvious, what with the grief marble sugar here and all--"

You're in the middle of gesturing at the very nice arrangement you made, when there's the intensely loud crashing booms of a lot of pistol fire.

"Homura?" you say, hopes rising as you spin about, looking for your friend.

A tinkling metalic sound behind you catches your attention, and when you look back, you see a whole bunch of deformed bullets hitting the ground.

"Huh. That's weird."

You look up at the very pale police officers nearby, who are holding guns toward you.

"Oh! Thank you, Homura likes guns a lot."

It's a moment of thought and will to disperse a few marbles of grief and use the foglets to gently accept the offered pistols from the police officers.

"We're still stocking up for Walpurgisnacht, you see. Pistols can help against her familiars."

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: There's a faint worry in the back of your mind that you're missing a lot of... the stuff that makes your brain work. Everything seems to be happening a LOT faster than normal. It's exciting, but also a little worrying. You resolve not to think about it too much, because you're not sure how one would go about putting a lampshade over an entire wall.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"I have some gold that we took from the Yakuza that I could give you, to reimburse you for your donations to the cause. I mean, not *with* me, I'd need to find it, but I know guns are expensive and you probably have a department budget to worry about. Actually, thinking about that, where am I?"

One of the officers starts to speak, when another thought occurs to you.

"Wait, no, first, *when* am I? And have you met any time-travellers? They're really good at hiding behind masks, but beneath the mask, they're still the same sad girl who cried over her only friend and just wanted to save her so badly she traded her soul for a wish, so if you see them, you should give them a hug -- but ask first! Very important to ask first. Oh, wait, no, have you seen any monsters? And I'm not talking about the philosophical monsters that lurk inside all of us, I'm asking if you've seen monsters that look like reality decided to start tastelessly scrapbooking."

The cops don't seem to know what to think, but they look rather scared. You don't blame them, witches and their familiars would be scary if you didn't have magic.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"It's okay, you don't need to be afraid, I'm good at protecting people from monsters, I think. I mean, I'm good at helping the people who protect people from monsters too. By the way, if you see any magical girls, tell them I can cleanse their soul gems, so long as they help people. That's what I do, but I'm not too shabby with the monsters either. Not as good as Mami, but..."

You really miss your girlfriend, and all the rest of your friends. You sniffle, and wipe away a few tears, then grimace at the strange, uncomfortable feeling of something inside your face that shouldn't move, moving about.

"Actually, do any of you have any aspirin? Someone hit me in the head *really* hard, and my head hurts. Or I think it should hurt, but I'm shutting out the pain from affecting me? Maybe? Everything feels really weird, and I'm having a hard time keeping my thoughts together."

One of the cops slowly moves forward, hands up in a classic placating gesture.

"We can get you medical attention. But first, I need you to set down your weapons, alright?"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You think it over slowly, and yet far too quickly at the same time.

"Yeah, I can do that. But you need to be careful with them, okay? If you're not careful with guns, they can hurt people."

The police officer nods slowly.

"I promise, we'll all be very careful with them."

Alright, that works. You carefully put their pistols back into the retention holsters on their hips, and snap the retaining loop into place, then bring the grief fog back over to nearby you.

"Did any of you want a hug?" you ask the pale police officers, "You look like you're not feeling well."

"We'll be fine. Thank you for giving those back to us. Can you put away your... other weapons?"

"Huh? What other weapons? Wait, what city is this, again? Sorry, I missed it when you told me."

"You're in Olympia, the capital city of Columbia. Now, would you be willing to put down the... black marbles?"

Wait, what?

"Colombia? That doesn't sound right, they speak Spanish there, and the capital is Bogotá, not Olympia."

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"Wait, what country am I in? This is really confusing, now."

"You're in the United States."

You focus for a moment, trying to remember anything about a Colombia besides the Spanish and British ones, before giving it up as a lost cause.

"Right, sorry about the grief marbles. I know they're freaky, that's why I made fructose molecules out of them. I mean,  not *real* ones, though I could do that. Damn, I should have done that."

As you apologise, you collapse the grief duplication and hide the little bit of *real* grief you have with you in four-space. For a strange moment, you feel like you could have, maybe *should* have, been in Chicago.

"I think I took a wrong turn at Albuquerque. I'm not in Bioshock, am I? Because if I am, I'm going to complain *so* much."

The police officer slowly shakes his head, carefully inching forward.

"No, you're not in a video game. You're very confused right now, so we're going to get you to a doctor, alright?"

You finally realize that they're pale because of *you*. You've done... something? Something that must have made them uncomfortable.

"Right. Sorry about... um, whatever it was that I did. I'm not normally like this."

"That's entirely understandable. Head injuries can make it hard to keep track of things, so it's important to stay calm."

That makes sense. You've been out of sorts ever since you got here, after all.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Wait, no it doesn't, you don't even think with your brain.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Heh.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
Actually, you should probably sit down and figure this out. So you sit down on the sidewalk.

"Right, let's get started. Do any of you have a history book on hand? I'm not from around this timeline, and my weird knowledge stuff apparently doesn't have auto-updates enabled, and I've lost track of that metaphor."

You can hear a helicopter approaching in the distance, and you're pretty sure there's more people heading this way. 

"We can get you a history book," the police officer answers in a soothing tone, "But you might want to hold off on reading it until you're feeling better."

Huh, the other cops who had been with this one are gone. You're not sure when that happened.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You shake your head again, feeling a moment of wooziness. This is *really* weird, you shouldn't be having this sort of problem. What were you doing again?

Right, there's a police officer! Maybe he can help you.

"Excuse me, officer, I'm trying to find my girlfriend. Her name is Mami Tomoe, or Tomoe Mami because Japanese names put the surname first.  She's about five-foot two-inches tall, blond hair in shoulder-length ringlets, with really pretty eyes..."

The police officer starts to look a little blurry, but you're not sure why. He says something to you, but you don't quite catch it.

"You were really pale earlier, and now you're blurry. Are you okay? If you're not, I can give you a hug. I do that a lot. Sometimes, when something has gone really wrong, and I can't fix it, and the only thing I can do is give someone a hug. I should be able to fix it. What's the point of me if I can't fix things?"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: The police officer says something else, but you're distracted by the thought that you should probably check your soul gem. You pull it off of your lapel and look at it. It's all white and shiny and rhombussy and kinda griefy, but far more important than any of that, is the tiny, tiny line you see on it. A very shallow, very short *fracture*. In your soul gem.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"Oh," you say in a small voice, "Oh, that's... bad. That's really bad.

"Oh god. I don't... okay, I need to fix this. How can I fix this? Grief? No, that's bad, no putting that back inside my soul gem. Um... *Ummm...*"

You sniffle and wipe at your eye, ignoring the way your cheekbone crunches slightly inside your face, and look up at the pale police officer.

"Do you know of a really good jeweller? One who works with souls? Or a soul expert? Mine is kinda broken."

The officer looks confused for a moment, before nodding.

"We'll find someone to fix your brooch," he says in a placating, 'talking to a crazy person', sort of tone.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"I'm not crazy. I'm just..." you swallow and let out a bark of bitter laughter, "Oh god, I actually *am* brain-damaged now, or the magical girl equivalent. I'm literally *cracked*."

The laughter turns into a sob.

"I don't want to die. If it was saving someone, if it was fixing the world, making sure people were happy, sure, but not like *this*."

You quietly cry, staring into your soul gem, steadily siphoning away the thin trickle of grief you're producing.

A moment later, you feel an arm wrap around your shoulders, the police officer sitting down next to you.

"You're not going to die, alright? I won't pretend I understand even half of what you're talking about, but with what you were doing... if you protect people from monsters, then you owe it to them and to your friends to hold on, alright?"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You nod tearfully. He's right. You have people you need to get back to, people you need to protect.

"Y-yeah. It's just... imagine looking in the mirror and seeing you have a hole in your head, and you can *see* something is wrong with your brain, and suddenly all the weird things that have been going on make sense."

Despite the nod from the officer, you're pretty sure he doesn't understand.

"Okay, this?" you hold up your soul gem so he can see it more clearly, "Imagine this is a crystal-based computer that's powerful enough to perform all of the calculations that are needed to *fully* emulate a human brain. As part of being turned into a sort of super-soldier for fighting against malevolent entities which exploit exotic physics for their offensive and defensive capabilities, my mind was uploaded into this device. It operates on similar exotic physics, which permits me to remotely operate my body with full sensory bandwidth and minimal latency, so long as it is relatively nearby. Because of this, I'm able to ignore debilitating pain, at only a mild reduction in reaction time, and I could even theoretically survive the complete destruction of my existing body, and be able to reconstruct it later."

He nods slowly, looking more than a little troubled.

"So right now I'm going to get some of the stuff I hid away, because I need to try to fix this. I don't think you have any doctors or technicians who can repair exotic physics devices like this, so I need to make with the *physician, heal thyself*."

Before he has a chance to respond, you pull the handful of grief you have available to you out of your pocket dimension and start carefully kneading it while trying to pour happiness, compassion, and hope flavored magic into enchanting it. You keep an eye on your soul gem, though, making sure that doing this isn't making things worse.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
The police officer stiffens as the grief appears, and it suddenly occurs to you that you haven't been very coherent, and you think you might have broken some things and had people running away from you earlier?

"Hey, um... I... I didn't hurt anyone, did I?" The thought of having hurt someone makes you feel ill.

"There were some injuries," he admits carefully, "Nothing too severe, though they're still being checked over by doctors."

You close your eyes, pained. Not as bad as Sentai, but you're not fighting Ramiel this time, or a city-destroying kaiju-witch. Wait, did you use Mecha Gurren Zilla Lagann in that fight? Or was that against the mercenaries from...

"What is it you're looking to do with that... black goo?"

The question snaps you out of your jumbled thoughts.

"I'm making a cast, or a bandage. The analogy is a bit messy, because it's not normal physics on either side, but that's close enough for contracting work. I might go into a trance when I start applying the band-aid, if I do, make sure nobody tries to take the gem away from me -- if they do, it might unleash something far, *far* more destructive than I could ever be, even if I tried as hard as I could."

"I'll make sure," he reassures you, and while you're too out of it to be certain, you'd like to think he's being sincere.

You wrap your soul gem in the enchanted grief, and *will* it to start working.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You shut out the world around you. You shut out the body you're connected to. You are a soul, within a stone, and you are operating on yourself with the energies that you create. Or maybe the energies that you *are*, you're not certain on that point. You pour hope and grief out of yourself and into the focus of your will.

You've never delved this *deeply* into your magic before, but this isn't a time for half-measures. An eternal instant passes, filled with impossible structures and patterns of the fullest range of emotion and thought, all the things you could ever possibly think or feel or experience, everything that you could ever possibly have been and still be *you*. You can see what the Incubator meant when he said your soul was *strange*, and why Riona reacted the way she did...

When you open your eyes, you find that you're looking up at a ceiling of some sort. You're laying down, and can feel a vaguely jostling movement running through you, as if the world was moving around you. There's a cold, metallic feeling around your left wrist, with a strange coolness running up your arm. Your soul gem is still in your right hand -- and looking at it, the fracture looks to have been filled in with a complex network of tiny golden threads, like the world's most complex stitching. It reminds you of Mami, in more ways than one.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
Huh. Your left wrist is cuffed to a bit of metal on the side of the little bed you're on. The handcuff looks fairly ordinary, all things considered. You also notice they put an IV on the same side, probably because the officer told them not to mess with your soul gem.

You feel... somewhat more clear-headed. Enough to know for *certain* that you're not entirely healed. Time feels strange, you're not quite as *aware* of things as you should be, and the very *way* you're thinking feels... *reduced*.

You're not back to normal, and you're not sure you ever will be, but for now you're...

Functional.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You look around for some button to call a nurse. You realize that the reason why you felt like the world was moving about is because the bed you're in has people pushing it along into what looks an awful lot like an emergency room.

Huh.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"Hi," you say, and wave at the nice people pushing the bed... cart... thing, "Just so you know, I'm alive. I can walk, too."

"Ma'am, please try to stay still," one of them says to you in that stern-yet-caring voice that just *screams* 'nurse' at you. Around you, others are talking rapidly. You hear something about anaesthesia, broken bones, blood transfusions, and internal damage?

Wait, hey, hold up, why are they trying to take your shirt off?!

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"Hey! What do you think you're--"

Your indignation is cut off when you see the spectacular, angry bruising along your side. Your ribs don't quite look right, and there's a weirdly squishy sort of puffiness that you're pretty sure is from internal bleeding.

"Oh, wow, okay, point taken."

Holding up your soul gem, you immediately start healing yourself. The sudden glow causes a few of the people around you to recoil for a moment, before they get back to work. Huh. Eh, they're emergency room doctors, steady nerves are part of the job.

You're pretty sure that they're trying to put you under, or at least get you to stop moving.

"It's okay, the light is me healing myself. You don't have to, oh, wow, that's unsettling to see."

Watching as surgeons start operating on you is... *fascinating*, in a vaguely nauseating way.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You continue pouring your magic into healing some of the deeper injuries, trying to avoid healing the incisions the doctors are making. You don't want them to get frustrated, after all. Instead, you pull the small amount of grief from your soul gem. You take a moment to collapse it into a marble, then clone it, and form a half-dozen hands.

"Jesus, Mary, and Joseph," someone mutters under their breath.

You try to give them a reassuring smile, without moving.

You don't think it reassures them.

Oh well, you tried.

Your hands get to work helping them out, with practiced ease. You're not terrible well versed in open surgery, but you can follow instruction. After a bit, they seem to just go along with it. The visible effects of your healing surprises them, but they continue working despite that. It *does* help you a bit, because it's easier to heal something when it's already set into place with the holes stitched up.

They're even kind enough to hold your cheek and forehead in place as you heal your face, despite the fact that you could have done that on your own.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
As they start sewing you up, you decide to make them an offer.

"So, I was thinking, is there anything I can help out with around here? You guys have seen what I can do, it works on other people too. I could sterilize the operating room?"

That gets a few looks being traded back and forth overhead. The doctor who is closing the incisions in your side answers.

"While the offer is appreciated, I don't think that's something the hospital could sign off on. Red tape and liability."

Ahh, yeah, that would be a problem. One you're not really used to thinking about. You're used to dealing with magical girls and fighting witches. Speaking of, you take a moment to scan about for magic and grief. What you get is *weird*. The people around you are all slightly more present to your magic and grief senses than ordinary people normally are, *almost* to the extent of a potential magical girl. Stranger still, there's a very faint amount of grief just in the ambient environment.

One oddity that you notice, is that the area around you doesn't have any other people milling about. There's people in the rooms nearby, but they're all standing still and facing the room you're in. Despite the windows on the doors, you don't spot any of them, as they're standing outside your line of sight. From the way they're standing... well, you can recognize an L-shaped kill zone when you see one.

Apparently they're a bit nervous about you.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
Well, you can't exactly blame them for being worried, but you'll deal with that later. Right now, you need to finish healing yourself.

"What's going to happen now?" you ask them, wondering if they even know about what's going on outside the room.

"Well," the surgeon answers in a brusque, yet oddly reassuring tone, "After we get you patched up, there are some people who are wanting to talk to you."

You fail to entirely suppress a wince, but the sudden movement barely slows the surgeon down, the stitching still straight and even.

"Sorry about all the trouble and, uh, damage. Do you know who I'm supposed to be talking to?"

"The police. Anything beyond that isn't my concern."

Less than a minute later, the surgeon finishes closing you up, and shortly after that, you finish healing yourself.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
With the surgery finished, you disperse the grief-hands into gas and reform it as a thin, transparent coating on your soul gem. You'd rather not take the risk of something causing even more damage.

"So, you wouldn't happen to have a Soul Damage ward at this hospital, would you?"

"Uh, no," one of the doctors answers in the sort of tone one uses when someone asks you something really crazy, but you're worried they might flip out and rip you to shreds if they get upset.

You nod decisively.

"Alright, I thought I'd ask. New world, and all of that, since I don't think the US where I'm from was like this. Anyway, I'm ready to talk to whoever," you say, and then sit up. Despite trying to do so in a non-threatening way, the doctors still recoil from you a bit. You move to hold up your hands placatingly, only to accidentally break the handcuffs attached to your wrist. The doctors all *rush* out of the room at that.

"Wait, no, I'm not-- dammit."

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
Well, damn. Alright, you don't want to freak anyone out, and from what you can feel, the ambush waiting for you outside hasn't moved at all. So you're just going to lie back down. You pull a drab of grief out of your soul gem and use it to collect the broken link from the chain of the handcuff, and put it back into place. It's not like it restrains you at all, but it'll send a message.

You lay there for a few minutes, trying to grasp the *way* you're thinking. The damage to your soul gem, to your mind, is subtle and yet fundamental. You're going to have to try to be careful of *everything* you do, now. There's a lot that you've taken for granted before, that you can't now.

Someone new enters your sensory range, moving closer at a brisk walking pace. They pass right through the cordon around you, and then pass through the doors into the operating room you're in. You take a moment to try your best to *take in* the person you're seeing, because this is probably going to be a rather important conversation.

Human male, caucasian, mid-40s, black hair, blue-gray eyes, 185-190cm, leaner build, black tie suit, brown overcoat still wet from rain outside. ID dangling from a lanyard has the name "Miller" clearly visible, along with the letters "CSPD" over an imprint of a vaguely Old Western feeling six-pointed star set in a circle.

He also looks vaguely unsettled as he looks at you.

Right, time for some top-shelf diplomacy.

"Be not afraid?"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
The guy just stands there for a moment, looking like he's trying to work through what you just said.

"I'm sorry about scaring everyone. I hadn't meant to, I'm just a bit out of sorts. People are probably upset about the damage I've done, but I can repair all of that. I'm normally not that obvious and destructive, but--"

You shake your head sharply, cutting yourself off before you start to ramble.

"You were wanting to talk to me, so, what did you want to talk about?" you ask and give a reassuring smile, or at least what you hope is one.

The man nods in return.

"I'm Lieutenant Charles Miller, with the Columbia State Police. Can I ask what your name is?"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
Right, just act naturally. No scaring the nice police officer.

"Sabrina Vee. Sierra-Alfa-Bravo-Romeo-India-November-Alfa, Victor-Echo-Echo. I don't think you'll find me anywhere, though. Well, except right here, obviously. Because I'm not from around here. Originally, that is," oh brilliant, maybe you should have acted unnaturally, "Anyway, uh, how much trouble am I in?"

Lieutenant Miller writes down something on a little pad of paper in his hand.

"Well, that's what we're trying to figure out. Would you mind answering a few questions? To help things move a bit faster."

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"Of course," you nod. You're not exactly happy about this, especially with how little you're finding out about things, but you can't exactly blame him for doing his job, "Though, uh... how many people did I hurt? Are they going to be okay? The police officer before said it wasn't too bad, but..."

Lt. Miller flips back a page in his notepad.

"About half a dozen minor injuries, the most severe of them being a shallow laceration along the left arm. With how much property damage you did, the number of injuries is fairly low. Though we're not certain about the pilot and crew of a helicopter you... *yelled* at?"

He seems puzzled at that, and so are you for a moment, until you remember your megaphone.

"Are they alright? What happened to them?"

Did they crash and go missing? Did you *kill* innocent people in your--

"They're reporting headaches and difficulty concentrating, but no hearing damage."

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You wince slightly.

"Sorry about that. I had just been injured in a way that affected my thinking, and I was trying to find my girlfriend. I didn't mean to scare them, or *hurt* them. I can look to fix whatever I did, if they keep having problems."

The lieutenant nods and writes down something.

It's at this moment that you realize that the doctors cut your shirt and coat off. You're laying on the operating table, covered in bloody handprints, naked from the waist up and not much better than that from the waist down. You promptly add some more red to your bloody color scheme by blushing brightly, as you move your free arm to cover up a bit.

"Uh, sorry, but can I reform my clothes? Or if that's not an option, can I get a hospital gown? Or something?"

"Reform your clothes?" Lieutenant Miller asks, curious and confused.

"Don't mind if I do!"

You take a moment to reform your clothes, taking especial care to minimize the light-show and noise. It still startles the officer, but not much more than that. For a moment, he looks like he's about to ask about it, but he holds off on it.

"The pyrotechnic display you performed on top of the Excalibur Building," he says instead, "How did you do that, and why did you do it?"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"Right... okay, I'm *basically* something sort of like a super-soldier who uses exotic physics effects to fight against other beings which use similar exotic physics effects to prey on humanity. The glowing crystal on my coat? Imagine a supercomputer powerful enough to run a total brain emulation upload, which then operates the original body via more exotic physics. Around the time I arrived here, that device was damaged. I've only just recently been able to effect a field-expedient repair. The reason why I created a..."

You frown.

"What *did* I create?"

Lieutenant Miller pulls out a sleek looking smartphone, taps a few times, and holds it toward you. On the screen is a picture of the top of a building that looks like an enormous downward-pointed sword, and floating above the "pommel" as it were, is a football-field sized heart made of ominously glowing golden gas that's crackling with electrical arcs that keep grounding into the building.

Well, that's a little embarrassing.

"Ah. I think I was trying to create a neon light. Looks like I forgot the glass. Um, it was *supposed* to be a heart. I wasn't exactly thinking clearly, due to the damage to the thing where my thinking *happens*. I made that because I was trying to find my girlfriend. If she had seen it, she would have realized it was me right away. I'm... a long way from home."

Worry claws at your insides. You have no idea what happened to smack you out of reality. Mami must be worried sick. *You're* worried sick. You don't have any of your usual things on you. No ribbon, no pendant, no bag, nothing. You don't even have *yourself*, not really, not *fully*. If you did, no-one would have gotten hurt, after all.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You close your eyes and quietly thank Madokami that you didn't hurt anyone worse than you did. You're so far out of your depth, here...

*"Hey Madoka? I know I probably messed things up, when I was supposed to fix them, but if there's any hint you can give me, any help, that'd be... really good right about now."*

"Your girlfriend being one Tomoe Mami, from Japan?" Miller asks, drawing your attention back out to the world around you.

You nod, and swallow.

"Yeah. Mitakihara City, Miyagi Prefecture. I don't know if it even exists in this world -- there wasn't a state called Columbia in the United States where I'm from."

The lieutenant nods, writing more things down.

"I assume that the other unusual things you've done are attributed to these 'exotic physics' effects?"

"Yeah," you nod, "It's hard to really explain at a more fundamental level than that. I mean, can you explain how your pistol, taser, body armor, and cellphone all work?"

"I can, actually," he smiles briefly, before giving an acknowledging nod, "But I understand your point."

"It probably helps that you can just look it up," you grouse, "I don't exactly have that luxury."

"That it would. Now, do you know what happened to cause your injuries? Or how it was that you came to be here, since you're so far from home?"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"Honestly, I'm not certain. Probably because of the damage. But I'm pretty sure that they're related. 'Bitchslapped out of reality' comes to mind. Whoever it was, they took me out of the picture without actually *killing* me."

Someone who would want you out of the picture, but not dead. Black feathers. You don't need to be a detective to connect *those* dots.

"Do you think this assailant could pose a danger to anyone else?"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You think for a moment and nod.

"Yeah. If it's any of the suspects I have in mind. There aren't very many motives for someone to get rid of me, and fewer that would do so in a way that would leave me alive. And all of those would be very dangerous... but I don't think they *could* be dangerous to anyone here. I haven't put much research into interdimensional... interplanar? Whatever, cross-universe travel, so I'm not sure how far from home they could reach, and some of them wouldn't even care about this reality at all."

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
Miller nods and absently scratches at his ear with the eraser end of his pencil, then writes down a few more words.

"Would you mind recounting to me your encounter with the police officers on Thomas Payne Street? That would be shortly before you were brought to the hospital."

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You nod and quickly start recounting to him everything you can about your perspective on your meeting with the police officers. You ask him a few questions, to clarify what happened, and he explains.

The explanation feels vaguely worrisome. When you think about it more, you realize that the most worrisome thing is that you have no clear memories of *any* of it. Everything after he asked you to recount what happened is a vague blur of impressions.

"*Dammit*," you say, frustration blooming in full force. You angrily dash away a few tears, and take a sharp breath.

Lieutenant Miller gives you a sharp, inquisitive look.

"I... I don't remember what we were just talking about, Lieutenant. It's frustrating to not *work* properly," you laugh miserably, "I guess my brain damage was acting up again."

"You explained how you met Officers Ramirez, Stevens, and Lee," Miller explains sympathetically, "It was clear that your ability to properly keep track of events around you was impaired. When the officers interpreted your gesture as an attack and fired on you, you used your 'grief marbles' to intercept the bullets."

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"Right, that makes sense. I've done that sort of thing before, but I didn't do it consciously. I've never *done* that unconsciously before," you say thoughtfully, before dismissing the tangent, "I'm sorry about scaring the officers, too."

You can fully imagine how terrifying that must have been, to have this insane thing babbling nonsense at you, and your weapons completely useless. A shiver of horror runs through you.

"I'll make sure to pass that on to them," Miller says, as he takes another note.

"So, what *is* the plan for me? I know that after a scene like that... well, I doubt that you'll just let me walk away... but I'd rather make this right instead of just..."

You trail off, grasping for words, but unable to fully articulate your **need** to make things right, to fix what's been broken. It's your ***purpose***, the reason you exist. You can't ignore that, you wouldn't *want* to be able to ignore that.

Lieutenant Miller scratches at his ear again.

"I'm not entirely certain what the higher ups are intending to do with you, but considering how cooperative you've been, especially with your previous impairment, I'm going to recommend a lighter touch, as it were."

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"That's... that's a relief, thank you. And... if you could pass on a thank you to the officer who stayed there to talk with me? I'd want to thank him for being understanding and, well, I really needed..."

You trail off again, this time from awkwardness.

Miller nods, "I'll let Ramirez know."

"Thank you. I, uh, I don't suppose you could be more specific about what's going to happen now? It's a bit worrying."

The only reason it isn't even more worrying is because you have too many other worries crowding it out, and your confidence that if all else fails, you can simply escape.

Lieutenant Miller thinks for a moment, and sighs.

"If you would be willing to cooperate further, we can take you into custody. We'll keep you away from anything that might cause you issues, and we'll see if there's anything further we can do to help you recover from this incident. All of your actions have been within the state of Columbia, and Columbia has very strict standards regarding culpability. With your injuries? Our main concern would be to make sure that you won't hurt yourself or anyone else."

Something about the way he's speaking makes you think that Miller isn't just talking to *you* with that.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
You frown, and nod.

"It doesn't sound terribly pleasant, but it's reasonable, for now. Do you have any more questions for me right now? Because I'm pretty sure that the hospital would like to have their ER back, and it's a bit of a mess over here."

Miller shakes his head, closing his notepad and putting it away.

"No, nothing right now. If you'd like, I can remove the handcuffs for you."

"Ah, I was just about to ask you about that. I don't want to break them again."

"I can't imagine that the handcuffs are doing anything other than making you uncomfortable, anyway," he says as he approaches, pulling out a set of keys, and unlocking them from your wrist and from the gurney.

"Well... yeah, I could have disassembled them and reassembled them, but I didn't want people to be even more worried. I've already done enough there, I don't need to add to it," you admit.

"The thought is appreciated," Miller replies with a small grin, "You'd be surprised how few people think about de-escalation."

You think back to your misadventures with a pang of loneliness. All your friends...

"Nah, I *know* how few people think about it," you say as you carefully sit up and get off of the gurney, "Nothing like showing up to a battle in progress that's on course to wreck an entire city, and trying to get people to sit down and just talk it out like reasonable teenage girls, only they're not reasonable, because *teenagers* and PTSD and resource conflicts..."

Miller raises an eyebrow.

"So I take it that most of your 'super-soldier' peers are the same demographic as you?"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
"Yeah. Back home, the others like me are all children and teenagers. The youngest one I know is about seven, and the average survival time is... painfully short," you grimace, and suppress a growl of anger, "We're recruited by an amoral manipulative little bastard that goes by the name Kyuubey. We're the targets because we're the ones most likely to accept the deals we're offered without asking too many question, or noticing all the *technical truths* we're being given. Then, we have to fight over the resources we need to survive, which when we're done with them, goes right back to Kyuubey. Between conflicts over limited resources, good old fashioned human conflicts, and Kyuubey stirring the pot, the rat-faced little **fuck** keeps us from being able to work together."

Miller nods slowly.

"Understandable why you'd get upset about that," he says in a calming tone.

You realize quite suddenly that your fists were clenched together so hard that your fingernails must have cut into your hands, because there's blood dripping onto the floor.

"Dammit, sorry. I just... I had been trying to work to solve that, and now I'm suddenly..." you shake your head, and unclench your fists. Your fingers pop and creak in protest, and your palms are smeared with blood.

You take a moment to heal the cuts.

"I think," you start slowly, "That it might be a good idea for me to be kept away from other people for a bit. I need to get a handle on how badly my mind has been damaged, maybe see if I can do anything more to fix it."

"Then if you'll come with me, we'll get you squared away."

You nod and head out the door of the operating room with him. The ambush waiting outside must have moved off at some point, because they're not there when you leave.

lines.content: if the cat is willing and able — let the *cat* investigate the door while the dogs are there

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: sniff at each other under the door, etc.

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: you'll have to put up with any noisyness from that for now — *don't* shoo any of them away unless violence is somehow ensuing *through* the door

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: *ideally* your second step is to kennel the dogs for just a few hours and let the cat explore the house freely for a bit

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: I understand if the roomies might be hesitant about that

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: but you want the cat to be able to get to know the new home without being hassled

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: and she has to be free to move to do that, you can't just move her around and "show her" the place

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: yeah

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: *ideally* what you'd do is let the cat *out* of the room and put the dogs *in* the room for that time

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: and do that several times over the course of a week or so

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: since the dog is *not* obsessively digging at the door trying to get at the cat, this should be relatively easy

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: yeah

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: once both the cat and the dogs have calmed down a bit, you introduce them in person — leash the dogs, and have them and the cat in the same room

lines.author: Celti
lines.content: if any of the animals are obviously terrified and/or overly aggressive (not *curious* or *defensive*, but actually *aggressive*), go back to the letting each of them explore the others' territory for another few days and try again

A long moment of silence, as Oriko's jaw works. You wait, seeing if she'll actually be useful now.
